Comments_List: I learned a lot from this course. It really made concepts from linear algebra and calculus make concrete sense.

Learned a lot about how biology ties in with computer systems, and how we can build on basic principles to generate complex vision algorithms and "artificial intelligence" based on visual input. Learned how to make sense of pixels in an image by applying different algorithms to the data to pick out features or classify them.

Lectures were interesting for the most part, but near the end of the semester they became very dense and hard to follow. TA hours were useful, but I was mostly unable to attend due to family concerns (daycare, etc.)

Lecture notes were very useful, but obviously in a draft stage, as there were many missing figures or typos or unclear text.

Homeworks were great and very helpful at understanding some of the more complicated theories.

It was never totally clear what we were expected to know for exams. There were occasionally details that were briefly mentioned in class and easy to forget by the time exams rolled around.

I would recommend this to anyone who is looking for a way to understand how linear algebra and calculus apply to concrete problems. Also, for anyone who is interested in neural networks and some of the fundamentals of classification algorithms.
Yes. Lots of very interesting ideas, especially for a computer science student.
absolutely, Professor Zucker perfectly combine computer vision with fundamental biology knowledge which greatly helps students develop interests and understanding.
